bibl.title: Letter from Louis A. La Garde to the Secretary of War, William Howard Taft, May 30, 1905

div1.p: La Garde requests to be relieved from duty.

div1.head: Letter from Louis A. La Garde to the Secretary of War, William Howard Taft, May 30, 1905
div1.opener:
COPY
ANCON HOSPITAL.
Ancon, May 30, 1905.
The Military Secretary
To the Secretary of War,
War Department, Washington, D.C.
(Through the regular channels)
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to request that I be relieved from duty in connection
with the Isthmian Canal Commission at such time as may be convenient to the
War Department.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, (Signed) Louis A. LaGarde,
Major and Surgn. U.S.A. Copy for Surgeon-General, Washington, D.C.

div1.head: Letter from H.R. Carter
div1.opener:
1st Endorsement
OFFICE OF DIRECTOR OF HOSPITALS
Ancon, C.Z., June 1, 1905.
div1.p:
Respectfully forwarded to the Military
Secretary for the Secretary of War,
through the Chief Sanitary Officer.
div1.closer:
(Signed) H.R. Carter
Acting Director of Hospitals. ************************** ********************

div1.head: Letter from the Chief Sanitary Officer
div1.opener:
2nd Endorsement
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER.
Ancon, C.Z., June 2, 1905.
div1.p:
Respectfully forwarded to the
Governor of the Canal Zone, approval
recommended.

I wish at the same time to express
my appreciation of Dr. LaGarde's service
at Ancon Hospital during the past year.
The hospital has been organized under hi
control and has done for the Department
a most useful work.

Dr. LaGarde personally has done a
great deal of the capital surgery of the
hospital, and his success in this line
inspired the whole force with confidence
in the work done at this institution.
